subheading: Educational tool for doctors and students

aiblock.block1: Personal clinical assistant for medical students and doctors. Helps structure knowledge, analyze clinical cases, prepare for exams and accreditation. Trained on a million verified medical data in accordance with the principles of medicine.
aiblock.block2: A repository of structured information for quick access. The knowledge base contains articles about AI and everything you need for modern medical education. The data is organized by topic, making it easy to find the information you need and use it in your studies and practice.

aboutUs.info1: To form a community of doctors of the future — those who use modern technologies to be competent and ready for real work.
aboutUs.info2: The AInterMed team is a community of doctors who have gone through the difficult path of medical university education themselves and know it from the inside. The product was developed by doctors and IT specialists, taking into account the real needs and standards of medical practice.

0.name: Alexey Smirnov
0.text: I usually use the neural network when we cover complex topics in class. It helps me retain the material faster. It's a handy tool for finding verified medical articles.

1.name: Elena Ivanova
1.text: I am very cautious about AI, but I have had no problems with this service. I have not noticed any errors in the answers. I receive detailed answers to my educational queries; the main thing is to ask the right questions.

2.name: Igor Petrov
2.text: This service saved me during exam season. I had a difficult exam in pharmacy in the winter, and thanks to AI, I didn't have to waste time searching for information. The result was a 5.

3.name: Maria Kozlova
3.text: I had been looking for a reliable and fast source of medical information for a long time, and AinterMed exceeded all my expectations. The site doesn't just provide information, it calculates indicators, whether it's body mass index (BMI), risk assessment, interpretation of tests (e.g., GFR calculation, ratio assessment), or something else — you enter your data and get a ready-made result with clear explanations.

4.name: Chisenga Lungu
4.text: I am studying medicine as a foreign student. I use the service to prepare for my exams. AI helps me translate medical terms from English into Russian.

5.name: Svetlana Orlova
5.text: I use your service regularly — it is really useful and clearly explains various aspects, and it does an excellent job with differential diagnosis. My only suggestion is to add the ability to upload images. As for the other features, I really like them. The answers are clear and structured.

6.name: Slyugrov Nyurgun
6.text: A very convenient and useful platform for medical students and doctors. It creates clear diagrams and tables for differential diagnosis and helps you quickly understand complex topics. For medical students, it will be useful not only for preparing for university exams, but also for international certification exams. I use the official ChatGPT subscription for $21, and this platform costs 299 rubles — for this price, it is incredibly profitable. It works quickly, stably, and answers medical questions much better than many other resources.

7.name: Anna Zhamina
7.text: I use your service regularly — it is really useful and clearly explains various aspects, and it does an excellent job with differential diagnosis. It's the best solution for saving time when studying. My only wish is to add the ability to upload images. As for the rest of the features, I really like them. The answers are clear and structured.

8.name: Victoria Volkova
8.text: I have been looking for a reliable and fast source of medical information for a long time — AinterMed exceeded all expectations. You ask a question and get a clear, structured answer based on current data. No need to read through dozens of pages — the service understands even complex queries. Plus, you can calculate BMI, GFR, test results, and other indicators with explanations. AinterMed saves time and really helps.

faq.a1: It is a platform created for medical students, interns, and young doctors. Using artificial intelligence technologies, we help users not only learn, but also remember and apply knowledge in practice.
faq.q2: How do I register on the platform?
faq.a2: To use the platform, you need to provide your email address and full name. The entire registration process takes 2 minutes.
faq.a3: The platform supports payment by bank card and various online payment systems. In addition, payment via the Fast Payment System is available, which ensures convenience and speed of transactions for all users.
faq.q4: What is the difference between free access and a subscription?
faq.a4: Free access provides a limited number of daily requests to AI, while a subscription opens up unlimited access and additional features.
faq.q5: How many questions can I ask?
faq.a5: The free version allows users to ask up to 4 questions per day, using only the General model. To remove this restriction and gain access to other models, we recommend purchasing a paid subscription.
faq.q6: How can I get unlimited access to the service?
faq.a6: Unlimited access to all features and materials of the service becomes available after purchasing a paid subscription. Subscribe to get full access without restrictions.
faq.q7: What sources does AI use for answers?
faq.a7: AI integrates recommendations and protocols from leading organizations: the World Health Organization (WHO), the British NICE Institute, the Association of Clinical Centers and Laboratories of the United States (ACLS), as well as official sources from the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation. In addition, the platform uses peer-reviewed publications from the PubMed and Cochrane databases, as well as international classifiers such as ICD-10, ATC, and other reference books.

q1.question: How to distinguish between bacterial and viral pneumonia?
q1.answer:
Bacterial pneumonia more likely to be sudden: high fever (>38.5°C), pronounced intoxication, moist cough with sputum. CT scan shows unilateral segmental infiltrates.

Viral pneumonia usually develops gradually: subfebrile fever, dry cough, dyspnoea. CT scan shows bilateral frosted glass areas.

q2.question: What to do when a diabetic has a sudden drop in sugar?
q2.answer:
If a person is conscious - urgently give 15-20 g of simple carbohydrates: juice, sugar, glucose paste. Check glucose levels after 15 minutes and repeat if necessary.

If the loss of consciousness - 40% glucose intravenously or 1 mg of glucagon intramuscularly.

After normalisation. - eating and reviewing insulin/therapy regimen to avoid recurrent episodes.

q3.question: What signs of infective endocarditis are seen on cardiac ultrasound?
q3.answer:
Major findings on ultrasound (especially through the oesophagus):

  • Movable formations on the valves are vegetations.
  • Abscesses, flail perforations, valve deformities.
  • New regurgitation not explained by other causes.

Diagnosis requires a combination of imaging.

q4.question: Why can troponin be elevated without a heart attack?
q4.answer:
Troponin elevation is not always associated with myocardial infarction. Possible causes:

  • Acute and chronic heart failure.
  • Myocarditis, tachyarrhythmias, pulmonary embolism.
  • Sepsis, severe inflammation, chronic kidney disease.

q5.question: When can antibiotics for pneumonia be discontinued?
q5.answer:
Antibiotics can be discontinued when:

  • Normalization of temperature (<37.5°C) for 48+ hours.
  • Improved well-being and breathing.
  • Decrease in SRB/leukocyte levels.

The course usually lasts 5-7 days, but it is important to be guided by clinical response, not just CT scans.

q6.question: How to distinguish COVID from flu and cold by symptoms?
q6.answer:
COVID-19 Often manifested by loss of smell, prolonged subfebrile fever, headache and dyspnea with an unexpressed cough.

Influenza begins abruptly, with fever, body aches and severe weakness.

Colds - milder course: runny nose, low fever, rapid recovery.

q7.question: What to do if your blood pressure drops to 90 over 60 and you feel dizzy?
q7.answer:
Low blood pressure can be a variant of normal or a signal of problems.

  • Lie down, lift your legs..
  • Drink water or a sweet drink.
  • Ventilate the room, keep it quiet.

If the dizziness does not go away, see your doctor. You may need to be tested for anemia.

q8.question: What tests are needed for a lingering cough?
q8.answer:
If the cough lasts >3 weeks, infections, allergies and chronic lung disease should be ruled out.

  • General blood test with leukoformula.
  • Fluoroscopy or chest CT scan.
  • cPCR/ ELISA for mycoplasma, chlamydia, COVID, tuberculosis.
  • If suspected, a sputum test, FWD or allergy panel.
